Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Testing metacommunity models in forested vernal wetlands using a multi-taxa, multi-year approach
Award.AbstractNarration:
Many natural areas persist as habitat patches within a larger developed landscape. Species communities in these patches fluctuate over time as a consequence of local extinction, dispersal between patches, and interactions between species. Metacommunity theory is an organizing framework for understanding how networks of communities assemble and change, and can help resource managers make decisions about habitat and species conservation. There is a strong need to test metacommunity theory, though, at field scales relevant to conservation questions. This project examines forested vernal wetlands, which provide ideal systems for testing metacommunity theory. Vernal wetlands may flood in the spring and dry completely each year and frequently contain species adapted to these unique environmental conditions. They tend to be small and difficult to detect on the landscape, but they provide critical breeding habitat for amphibians and aquatic insects. Insects, amphibians, plants, and water chemistry will be studied in sixty wetlands within Wisconsin's Chippewa Moraine region over five years in order to capture the effects of environmental variability on community structure. The role of more permanent wetlands as sources of organisms for vernal wetland communities will also be evaluated. Finally, field experiments will provide insight into how community history affects species presence and abundance. These studies will help determine the relative contributions of environmental variation, species interactions, community history, and landscape position on community composition.

Conserving forested vernal wetlands is a priority in efforts to protect aquatic biodiversity, and understanding how metacommunities function in these unique systems is critical to protecting them. Research findings from this project will be incorporated into ecological landscape management plans for use by forest managers. The project will involve numerous undergraduates in research experiences and will increase the number of under-represented groups and first-generation college students pursuing STEM fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We initiated the Chippewa Moraine Ephemeral Ponds Project (CMEPP) in order to test theoretical concepts from metacommunity ecology within the context of a system of ephemeral pond (EP) wetlands in western Wisconsin over a five-year time period. EPs are temporary wooded wetlands that dry during many years. They are critical habitat for amphibians and many unique invertebrate taxa. Metacommunities are a set of ecological communities connected to each other via the interchange (dispersal) of different species across geographic space. We also took advantage of the study design to compare the species communities in permanent and ephemeral wetlands.

For five years, we collected data on the plant, aquatic macroinvertebrate, and amphibian communities of 57 different ephemeral and permanent wetlands. We also collected soil, hydrological, and water chemistry data.

In terms of plant species communities, we addressed the important question of how EP vegetation differs from that of permanent wetlands in the understudied vegetation of temporary wetlands in eastern North America. We also addressed metacommunity concepts such as shared species and trends in beta-diversity between permanent and ephemeral wetlands. We determined that EPs do not have inherently low floristic quality, potentially meriting further conservation value (Fig 1).

We also demonstrated that EP vegetation is distinct from that of permanent wetlands, with particularly high proportions of woody, annual, and fern species (Fig 2). Our results suggest that this notion may be true for some individual EPs, but that as a class, their vegetation differs from permanent wetlands, which share, on average, <40% of EP species. The relatively small proportion of EP species that is shared with permanent wetlands suggests that permanent wetlands may be poor quality habitat for EP species, especially annuals, and that EPs are primarily responsible for maintaining them on the landscape.

Metacommunity theory investigates the varying roles of local environment, space, and relative species population sizes on ecological communities. The primary influence on these plant communities is the environment with some influence of space. Little variability is due to geographic space alone. Wetland groups demonstrated patterns of nested species loss, with smaller wetlands containing subsets of species found in the larger wetlands.

Our amphibian results suggest that spring peepers prefer wetlands with longer hydroperiod. There was high year to year variability in amphibian abundance that we have not yet explained.

Work on the invertebrate community indicated high variability among wetlands and among years, showing a need for longer term studies. Rare taxa in a wetland one year would often become abundant the following year, replacing taxa that once were once dominant. Local physical and environmental characteristics affect overall invertebrate community structure. There is a relationship between distances between wetlands and species communities for some invertebrate taxa. Different invertebrate groups respond differently to both spatial distance and local environmental conditions.

Different metacommunity mechanisms influence different subsets of invertebrate communities. In the future, we will determine how metacommunity models are associated with invertebrate taxa based on their dispersal strategies (e.g., active vs. passive dispersal). We will also investigate whether breeding status helps to explain why some taxa are more strongly associated with environmental conditions than other taxa. We will also explore annual variability in overall invertebrate communities.

An additional aim of CMEPP was to grow human resources in the sciences and promote the environmental science major at the University of Wisconsin-Stout, a polytechnic institution with a high proportion of first-generation and low-income students. Through our intensive field sampling program, CMEPP provided educational experiences to 72 undergraduate students. Nineteen undergraduates were provided with apprentice-style research training (employment), including nine female and five first-generation college students. Eight of the twelve crew leaders for the project were female, an under-represented group in environmental sciences. Undergraduate students presented fifteen different research posters at national and regional venues, for a total of 33 presentations by CMEPP personnel. Seven undergraduate students published five manuscripts in UW-Stout?s peer-reviewed Journal of Student Research.

We also developed an educational module on species diversity ephemeral and permanent wetlands. This module teaches students to use large datasets while learning about EP biology. EP research field experiences were integrated into Ecology and Wetland Ecology undergraduate courses.

Due to the large nature of the program, CMEPP will be providing data to other researchers through public repositories and generating manuscripts for years to come.

The project has made an impact on citizen and student knowledge of ephemeral ponds through multiple public presentations across the years. Teaching ecology and introductory biology students about ephemeral ponds makes an impact on society at large, because many of these students will go on in careers unrelated to ecology. Finally, our work is informing ecological managers? understanding of ephemeral ponds through site visits, workshop consultations, and incorporation in agency-sponsored publications.
